bestBHT.bht: According to the genealogical account in Ruth 4:19, Aram begat Aminadab, who in turn was the ancestor of Naasson, the prince of the tribe of Judah when the Israelites entered into Canaan.

John Gill: And Aram begat Aminadab,.... Which, with what follows in this verse, exactly agrees with the genealogical account in Ruth 4:19.
John Wesley: Naasson — Who was prince of the tribe of Judah, when the Israelites entered into Canaan.

bhtAttempts.bht: Aram begat Aminadab, who was the ancestor of Naasson, the prince of the tribe of Judah during the Israelites' entry into Canaan. This lineage is confirmed by the genealogical account in Ruth 4:19.

Aram begat Aminadab, and according to Ruth 4:19, this lineage is confirmed. It is worth noting that Naasson, a descendant of Aminadab, held the esteemed position of being the prince of the tribe of Judah during the Israelites' conquest of Canaan.
According to the genealogical account in Ruth 4:19, Aram begat Aminadab, who in turn was the ancestor of Naasson, the prince of the tribe of Judah when the Israelites entered into Canaan.

In accordance with Ruth 4:19, Aram was the father of Aminadab, who was the ancestor of Naasson. Notably, Naasson held the position of prince of the tribe of Judah during the Israelites' conquest of Canaan.
Aram begat Aminadab, and as it is recorded in Ruth 4:19, this lineage can be traced back to Naasson, the prince of the tribe of Judah during the time of the Israelites' entry into Canaan.
